title.narrative: Life-saving emergency WASH response to drought displaced IDPs living in informal settlements in Injil area in Herat Province and Qala-e-Now area in Badghis Province

description.narrative:
The project aims to address the lifesaving WASH needs of people displaced due to drought from Badghis, Ghor and Farah provinces. These internally displaced people (IDPs) are currently living in informal settlements (IDP camps) in Injil District of Herat and Qala-e-Now District of Badghis. The caseload is already established through a number of inter-cluster and interagency assessment missions and response has been ongoing since early May in Injil, Herat and since early August in Qala-e-Now in Badghis. This proposal is based on the WASH cluster strategy-note for AHF 6th Reserve Allocation (RA) 2018 and the RA strategy paper for Afghanistan and is in accordance with the national WASH cluster strategy, target and priority for the revised Afghanistan HRP targets for 2018 and 2019.
The proposed action will target the displaced families, especially young children, women, girls, boys, the elderly and the disabled living in the IDP camps in Herat and Badghis provinces. The IDP camps in Herat Province are based in Kharitstan, and Regreshun and Shahrakb. While the IDP camps in Qala-e-Naw in Badghis Province are mainly located at Baghlar and neighboring area, Jarikosh and neighboring areas and Sanjitak. Since there is a continuous movement of IDPs from one location to another, the exact number of IDPs living in each camp is constantly changing. For this reason, UNICEF and WASH partners (from separate funding mechanism), will make sure that 100% of drought IDP caseloads in Herat and Qala-e-Now are covered. UNICEF as the agency of last resort will coordinate all this effort. It is also important to note that the government is keen to relocate Herat IDPs in different location then in the areas currently served. If this happens and when it happens, project will mobilize remaining resources to cover the WASH needs of the IDPs in new location. In coordination with shelter cluster, 334 IDP families living in Firoz Koh will also receive hygiene support through distribution of hygiene consumables.
UNICEF uses partnership cooperation agreements (PCAs) to engage and work with NGOs and CSOs. In this case, NGO Coordination for Afghanistan Relief (CoAR) has been identified to support implementation. However, other NGOs such as DAACAR, World Vision with whom UNICEF has PCAs might also be used if required. The PCAs cover the period up to the end of the country programme (2015-2019). Partnerships with government counter-parts is based on rolling work plans that are signed and revised/updated on annual basis. UNICEF will use any of the existing (Government or NGO) implementing partners to undertake the proposed activities based on comparative advantage that a partner may have.
